sp.l: None, Old nor Young, Man, Woman Child, all
In one kinde or other, do feel Affliction.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Do any die?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: None, though the moſt do wiſh
They might, in lieu of their ſad ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: And whither now do you intend your travail with your griefs?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: VVe hope a better Air will cure us. But
VVe are advis'd by our Divines and Augurs,
By the beſt means we can, to make our Journey
Towards the Court, to ſend our ſad complaint
Unto the King.

sp.speaker: (Eul.
sp.l: Hear now what he will ſay)

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: They find by Divination, that this puniſh|ment
Is falne upon this Province by the Sin
Of the Adulterous Queen, whoſe Dowrie 'twas.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: And that until
His juſtice take away Her loathed life,
This evil will not ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, the Queen Eulalia's life?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes Sir; we hear ſhee's baniſh'd, and forbid relief:
But nothing ſave her polluted blood muſt quench this flame,
In expiation of her Sin and ſhame.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dare you ſtay longer here? pray let us flie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Why then you think me guiltie, Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not what to think, but that I will not.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Was that your Prieſts opinion and advice?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes, and thus grounded, that our pains began
Juſt at the hour, the Kings Indulgencie
Releas'd her forfeit Life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: 'Twas everſo; Prieſts are but Apes to Kings,
And proſtitute Religion to their ends.
sp.p: Might you not judge as well, it was th' injuſtice and the wrongs the innocent Queen hath ſuffer'd, that has brought ſenſe of her injuries upon her Pro|vince? And that if ſhe had died, her Dowrie here with her had alſo ſuffered Death? to make it nothing to the King, as he made her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I, mark ye that: and that your falſe ſurmiſe
Againſt the Queen has brought this evil on you.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: O now my pain increaſes. 1. O mine Eyes. 2. My Brain. 3. My Bones. 4. My limbs are on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, your fowl miſtruſt is the infection that rages in you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Lodovico, peace: where is thy pain good man?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: Here in this Arm ſhrunk up as it were ſear'd with fiery Irons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Bleſs'd Providence aſſiſt me whilſt with Prayers I uſe the gift thou gav'ſt me for the cure of theſe afflicted People. Give me thine hand: what feelſt thou now?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: A precious cooling Balm that has extin|guiſhed
The ſcorching heat I felt, and has reduc'd
My Fleſh, my Sinews, and my Arteries,
Into their natural temper and true uſe.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Joyn that hand to thy other, and thank Hea|ven then
sp.l: That made thee whole.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mira|culous!

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O ſure you are ſome Heavenly Saint or Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Beware Idolatry, and onely ſend
All praiſe to th' power whoſe mercy hath no end.
Onely do this for me: inform the reſt
How you have ſped, and win them back again,
To the next village: bid them be of chear,
Whilſt I make Holy Prayers for their help.
Ile come and live among you for my hire,
Which ſhall be cheap, believe me.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: All we have
VVill be too ſlight reward: firſt take my ſtore.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I will but take my next competent meal.
I hope this will be thought but valuable.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I pray take more.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go back I ſay with your ſad company,
And comfort them with news of your ſucceſs,
And a full hope of cure to every one
That's Partner in this ſad Affliction.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: With happy feet I ſhall ſpread it through the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O happy woman, now no more a Queen,
But Holy Saint: I ſee how Providence
Means to advance thy injur'd innocence.
Ile dwell here now my ſelf, and without fear:
For perfect health I think dwells only where
Good Eulalia remains: I have enough
To buy a Farm for me and poor Andrea.
But what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Ile tell you, Lodovico: the poor Fellow
Is gone to taſte the Countrey Air for me,
Leſt I might be infected: you ſhall ſee
Straight how he ſpeeds.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And that was honeſt love.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A Surgeon, a Surgeon! Oh a Surgeon!

sp.speaker: Eul,
sp.l: How now, Andrea?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: A Surgeon: Oh twentie Surgeons, bone|ſetting Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: What's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I am out of joynt. Ile taſte no more of ſuch contagious Aires, To ſave as many Queens as I have hairs. Oh Surgeons and Bone-ſetters, Bone-ſetters and Surgeons, all my Bones, all my Bones for a penny.
sp.l: I have not a finger nor a toe in joynt: my Leggs,
my Thighs, my Arms, my neck.
My back and Crupperbone is out of joynt.
Oh for a Sowgelder, a Surgeon I would ſay.
Out a joynt, out a joynt, I am all out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Thy tongue's not out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, nor a Thing
I have that has no Bone in't: All elſe is out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This came of tempting Providence: were not you
Told the danger by the many that ſmarted of it?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I met them all dancing and frisking home.
The blind man made the way: the dumb man ſung,
The deaf kept time to his Notes: the lame led on
The Dance to all the reſt: whilſt I can go
No further. [lies down] 'Twas for you I ventured.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: And now you repent you meant me ſo much good.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And now again I do repent that ever I did repent. Oh for a Stone-cutter, a Bone-ſetter I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVell Sir, give me your hands: ſtand up.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: VVith as good a will as ever I ſtood to wo|man.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Now, how do you feel your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: In very pretty plight, I feel I am ſufficient.
sp.p: Haugh, heigh— [Capers and turns] 'twill do again: and if I durſt venture into that unluckie Countrey again, I would now teach the Clowns how to Dance for joy.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes you ſhall venter Sir; and by the way,
Ile teach you to teach them to work and pray.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: To work and play I pray you,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If there be Heaven on earth, it is this woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Then if there be a Purgatorie on earth,
Ile venter through it for her, heigh, o, ho.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.l: 1. Health and Joy: Health and Joy.
2. O happy woman that ever ſhe came hither!
1. Nay happy we that ere ſhe came among us.
2. VVhat ſhall we render her in recompence?
All that we have is too little for this woman,
This good woman, this holy woman, this ſhe-Saint,
If there be one above ground.
3. O do not make an If at her, neighbour, leſt the ground ſwallow thee quick in thy Infidelitie.
2. Now doubtleſs, and without all adventure, ſhe is an unknown woman.
3. And therefore a good woman: for 'tis too true,
All thoſe that are well known are e'en bad enough:
And known ſhe will not be for all our entreats,
No not ſo much as from whence ſhe came, we ſee.
2. And that counſel ſhe may keep ſtill for me:
For doubtleſs, and without all peradventure
If we had need of another ſuch, 'it were in yain to ſeek her.
1. Sure 'twas from Heaven ſhe came,
Where the whole ſtock of good women vvere plac'd long ago.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe I'm confident.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Our work lies fairly then before us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Theſe look like miſchievous Robbers.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What can they take from us?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your Life, I fear.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I have e'en din'd, let 'em take away when they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Their looks are murderous.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Fear not, Lodovico: why look ye Friends, ſo amazedly? ha'ye loſt your way? or what do ye ſeek?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No, we ha' found our way, 'tis to you we ſeek: we dare come roundly to you, for all your
sp.l: Guard, your old Fool, and your young here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O my unhappy Fears!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You will not murder me?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis all the Office we are bound to doe you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Juſt Heaven protect me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Call upon Heaven as you go thitherward:
VVe may not ſtay long Invocations.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray take me in your way, and run me through her, if you be honeſt Murderers. Help: Murder, Murder!

div.head: Scoen. VII.
div.stage: Enter to them, Curate, Crier, Pedro, Lollio, Poggio.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes! O yes! O yes!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Silence Crier, ſuſpend the Proclamation, to preventa bomina|tion.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Heaven has ſent us ayd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O we are prevented!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
On, on; ſa, ſa; down with their VVeapons, up with their heels, till we inſect and rip up the in|trails of the Cauſe: what an Aſſaſſinate was here at|tempted?
O infauſta D●es! two ſwords againſt the naked vvomb of a VVoman! and none but weapon|leſs men to aſſiſt her!

sp.speaker: viz.
sp.l: Senex & Ineptus.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: That is to ſay, Give me their Swords un|der my Fools Coat, I'll hurt no body.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Upon my facundity, an elegant conſtruction by the Fool. So, I am cedunt arma Togae.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: For our attempt Sir, we vvill anſwer it: vve are for the King.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then vve are for the King, Sir; & in nomine
Majeſtatis, we command you to attend our preſent
Office, and then we will examine yours.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: And then if you deſerve the Gallows, you ſhall be ſure on't: a ſhort breathing-vvhile ſhall be no hinderance to you. So Crier lift up your Voice, and proceed.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes, O yes, O yes: By the Kings moſt Excellent Majeſty, a Proclamation, prohibiting upon pain of Death, any Relief to be given unto the ba|niſh'd Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now ſay, VVhereas upon juſt and lawful Tryal.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: VVhereas, &c.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The ſaid Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: The ſaid Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: I am that hapleſs ſhe, that for relief will not beg, nor borrow, nor take of yee.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe, and at the price of Life I vvill re|lieve her.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How? vvhat have vve done? In relieving her from killing, we are all become Traytors.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: That's an idle fear: vve knew her not,
VVhich now vve do, vve may again reliver her
Into their hands, for them to kill her yet:
And then there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: So let us give them their ſwords again; and
vvhen they have done their vvork, to make all ſure,
vve'll hang them for their pains, and ſo keep the Law
in our own hands vvhile vve have it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The woman muſt be ſav'd á manubus istis.
They are Catilinarian Traytors.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You Sir, have reaſon; you have found her Life
The King has pardon'd: and although her Doom
In this her Baniſhment were heavy, and
A puniſhment even unto Death, but that
Good ſoul ſhe works and labours for her food,
You find not yet 'tis lawful any kill her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Recte dixiſti Domine: therefore Sir,
You that are for the King, as you pretend,
Shew us th' Imperative mood or warrant for her death,
Or we ſhall put you into the Optativa mood,
By puniſhment to wiſh your ſelves dead oftner
Or more times than bona fide there be Tenſes
In all the Moods of all my Accidences.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: For my part Ile forgive them, if they will
Deliver truely who corrupted them,
To rid the world of this weary burden; that I may pray for them.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Can ſuch a goodneſs deſerve ſo fowl a Cen|ſure?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: But firſt tell me: Are not you two the men that gave falſe evidence at my Arraignment touch|ing injur'd Sforza?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We gave no evidence, nor falſe nor true.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: No countrey-woman, they had no ſuch Beards. But I will try if I can make'm like'em: O rare! what a nimble Barber am I? Lod. They are the ſelf-ſame men, the two caſhier'd Lieutenants that Sforza ſhould have hang'd for mutinies in the late Wars.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: What hinders now their execution?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Digito compeſce labellum: ſilence good Pedro.
I do commend your zeal: but Periculum eſt in via,
We will walk ſafely: for this time therefore wee'l do onely thus,
Double our guards upon 'em, and away to priſon with them,

l.hi: Eſt locus in carcere quod Tullianum appellatur.

sp.l: We will preſume to know who 'twas that ſet you awork, before you go,

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: You will be made to anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A word more, wee'l hang you preſently, and anſwer that too: Abite hinc in malam Rem: away with 'm.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: Ah Rogues, wee'l hamper ye.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: Kill a woman 'cauſe ſhe was a Queen?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Wee'l hamper ye, and halter ye, and do ye hear? hang ye.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lollio and Poggio, with Fabio and Strozza.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Abi hinc & malam rem, away with'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: As I am Erudite, idoneus Adoleſcens,
A very towardly Juvenis. Cupis at{que} doceri?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: After you is manners.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now by mine intellect, diſcreetly ſpoken.
Be but my Pupil, I will make thee one,
And dip thy Caput in pure Helicon.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Pray what's my Caput? and what's your Helicon?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Still a deſire to learn: this is no Fool.
And by the company hee's in, I do ſuſpect,
Simile non eſt Idem: hee's too wiſe,
To be the thing he ſeems but in diſguiſe:
Some Lord of Court, his outſide non obſtante.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It is confeſs'd Sir, I am Lodovico,
Somtimes a Lord of Court when this was Queen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O Oedipus! I meant this Juvenal.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No truely Sir, your Simile non eſt Idem.
I am no Lord, what ere you like me to.
What I may paſs for in the Country I know not,
At Court I was a Fool when ſhe was Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVe dare not call her Queen now: but while we
Relieve her not, though we aſſociate her,
VVe are the Kings true Subjects: and with your leave,
Diſclaiming of all Honourable Titles,
VVe'll live amongſt ye.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O gracious woman, ſo I may ſafely call you,
VVho once preſerv'd my life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Mention not that.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I ought not to conceal it: therefore know
That ſome years paſt being imploy'd to Court
To render the Kings Rents for this Province:
VVhich though I duely did, there was a Lord,
A ſtrange officious one, that charg'd me deeply,
And all our Province, with deteſted breach
Of our Allegiance: at which my rage
Baniſh'd my reaſon, and confounded ſo
My ſenſes, that without reſpect of Perſon,
Or Place, which was the Danger of the Law,
I ſtruck him there in Court: and was adjudg'd
To ſuffer death for't, till you won my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVere you that man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And 'twas my
Cozen Lord'I warrant that you box'd.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis he that braggs ſo much his truth unto the Crown; I need not name him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sed nunc quid ſequitur? Pray mark the iſſue of this Court quarrell. By the way,'tis well you have renounc'd all qualitie of Court.
sp.l: Here were no living for you elſe; for know,
Since this mans trouble, not a Gentleman,
Much leſs a Courtier dares breath amongſt us,
But be as you pretend and write, but Yeoman:
You ſhall live Jovially with us and welcome,
At your own charge, your own Viaticum.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: We have laid up
The murderous minded men in dungeon deep,
Clogg'd them with Ploughchains, Fetters and Horſe|locks.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: VVe'l teach 'm to kill Queens:

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: VVe mean this woman, this diſcarded Queen.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For all the Feaſts, the Triumphs and the Glories
That have been ſpent, at price of great Eſtates,
In celebration of my high Advancement;
For all the King has in his preſent being,
His Love to boot, aſſur'd in higheſt meaſure;
Me-thinks there is yet wanting an Addition
To crown my Happineſs: all's not ſafe hereafter;
I cannot ſafely ſay I am his Wife,
While th'other ſeems contented with a Life. Flavello!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Moſt Mighty Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O moſt Coeleſtial ſound!
Here's all your buſineſs granted.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Greateſt and beſt of Queens! All?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: See the Kings hand to all: do you miſtruſt me?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I onely look for the poor womans Pardon
That kill'd her Husband for his gelding the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: If you but manage the Profits of my Fa|vours with a diſcreet Hand now, you may ſoon finde the difference between a Mignion, and the Son of a Diſh-Maker.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I finde it in your Gifts, my bounteous God|deſs.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Oh Divine!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: And would preſume that
I my ſelf were worthy
A place i'th' Kalendar, might I do you Service,
That merited the ſmalleſt of your Graces.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Do you know the village where that woman lives?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Who, ſacred Deitie?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I'm very ſick to name her or her Son.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: O Eulalia; yes, the very Houſe: 'tis in your Majeſties way now, as you paſs to Nicoſia: the King is ready, Madam, and calls away; he longs to be at the end of his journey, to perform his Duty in the three Grants belong to you.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O but that Woman, and that hated Boy.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Eulalia▪ Madam?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Thou art a baſe
Ingrateful Villain to name her to me;
Thou hear'ſt me ſay, I dare not ſpeak her name,
Yet thou dar'ſt ſtab mine Ears again, with it.
Had ſome receiv'd the Favours thou haſt done,
Or could but dream of half▪thou'rt like to have,
I ſhould not fear her Ghoſt; but thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O let me take new ſpirit from your hand,
And ſay unto your ſelf, She is ſure dead.
But the King comes. I am enough inſpir'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will not onely have you guiltleſs, Sir,
But free from leaſt ſuſpect; let but a ſpark
Of Diſcontent appear upon your Look,
I'll rip the hollow cave that holds the fire,
And with Death quench it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I beſeech your Highneſs,
If any alteration in my looks
Be found, or read, let it as well be conſtrued,
It grows but from a filial fear t'offend.
I have forgot I had another Mother:
And humbly at the Feet of this I honour,
I beg her Ayd, to win your Favour towards me.
Moſt gracious Madam, if you knew the Truth,
The fair ſincerity I bear in Duty
Towards your Highneſs—

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For what reſpect, young Prince?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: The principal i'th' World: For that you have
My Fathers Love; and but to Wrong or Grieve you,
Were Stripes or Wounds to his Affection.
So much of my late Mother I remember,
To yield a Reverence to his Contentment, and ſhall for ever.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: My Lord, my Love, what pretty meaning have you?
Do you bring your Son to mock me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! my Alinda, he's no Son of mine,
That with leſſe Adoration dares look up
On thy Divinity, then the Aegyptians
Gave to the Sun it ſelf: but an out-caſt Baſtard,
And of the daring Giants ignorant Nature,
That war'd againſt the Gods.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: I would not move your Anger: pray let this win your Reconcilement.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O thou art gentle, and the life of Sweetneſs:
Come, my Alinda, I was calling you
To our intended Journey to Nicoſta,
Where ſolemnly I will perform my Vow,
To grant the three demands I promis'd you,
In the full view of our Nobility.
Which by the Cuſtome of my Predeceſſors
Have ratified and confirm'd the Power
Of Queens, and made them abſolute: have you thought
To ask things worthy of your Dignity,
Wherein I fully may declare my Bounty?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I, Sir, ſhall be ſo reaſonable, that
I doubt not upon the way, or there at very inſtant,
To crave paſt my Deſert.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O you are modeſt: but ask home, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: And by the way, Sir, let it be my Suit,
We give a Viſit to diſtreſt Eulalia;
Wherein we may do Charity fitting Princes;
(We may perhaps give Order for her Burial)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art all Goodneſs: Come, all Friends, Gonzago:
But thank her Clemency.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: An Earldome be thou ſure of, wiſe Flavello,
To add to thy improvements: Though it be
No full Diſcovery, I'll make it ſerve,
As I will faſhion it, to excellent uſe.
Poyſon or Sword thou heardſt him ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Elav.
sp.l: And in a menacing way: Now what may be
Conjectur'd by ſuch words, from men whoſe looks
Shew diſcontent againſt your Mightineſs,
Reſts moſt conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: VVrite, Flavello, write,
VVrite by that Copy in a States-Man's hand.
Alas, good men! I dare even ſwear for them,
How ere thoſe words might fall in their diſcourſe,
They had no thought of me: yet this ſurmiſe
Gives me an hint to try her Loyaltie,
Or make her once more guiltie: for my State
Stands by the King, as unto her his hate.
Read it Flavello.

quote.p: Moſt Royal and moſt wronged Soveraign Miſtreſs, be happily aſſured that the time of your Reſtoration is at hand: and thatby no loſs means then the death of that ſhe-monſter that uſurps your Dignitie. All ſhall be determin'd at Ni|coſia, by
Your devoted Servant unto death. Nameleſs.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: 'Tis well.
It needs no ſuperſcription: only ſeal it,
And think of your directions and diſguiſe.
'Tis but your half days journey: and be ſure
VVe are not far behind you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I flie, my Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now to the King,
Of whoſe deſpight I ſtill muſt ſharp the ſting.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No news of Lodovico yet, Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: None ſince he ſtole from Court upon the Baniſhment
Of that falſe wicked woman, whom I cannot
Name to your face or forehead, but I tremble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Becauſe you fear all horned Beaſts.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Loyalty forbid,
And my infallible Truth unto the Crown,
But I were ſenſible of the injury.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know thy Loyalty: but as for Lodovico,
How was my Judgement wrong'd in him!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thought my ſelf as ſafe in that mans Coun|ſel—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And ſo did I,
By my lov'd Loyalty, think my ſelf ſafe
In his Advices—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet methought he had
A kinde of ſlyneſs in his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, he had ever a kind of a ſlie look.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That ſtill methought I had a Genius
That check'd my forward love, and did inform me
That he would prove diſloyal: and for that cauſe,
To ſpeak plain truth, I never lov'd him truely.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVill your Majeſty believe me? I would I might never riſe
Into your Favour (and that I would not ſay
For all the Traytors Lands in your Kingdom,
VVhich were no ſmall reward) if that were not
Mine very own conceit of Lodovico
That Traytor; hang him: what ſhould I call him leſs?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet 'twas given out you lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: So 'twas thought your Highneſs did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that he was your yoak-fellow in the State.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, when he's hang'd he ſhall be King. How Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your Majeſty knows my thoughts: nay I thank my creation, I was ever
Juſt of your Majeſties mind from my Nativitie,
And in that faith Ile die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here's a true Stateſ|man now!
Go, ſend Gonzago to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My ſweet yong Prince?
I ſhall: but ere I go,
Let me inform your Highneſs in my thoughts
Of the ſweet Prince Gonzago: if ever King
VVas happy in a Son, you are in him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go, call him to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Cheriſh him, good my Lord:
Hee'l be a ſure ſtaff to you in your Age,
And prove a Stateſman quickly: I cannot think,
Except in him and your undoubted Queen,
Petruccio and my ſelf, True Loyalty lives.
And here he comes: obedience in his Face
Moſt brightly ſhining.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wait without Horatio.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My dread Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did you attempt
Againſt my ſtrict command to viſit Sforza?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: It is moſt true, I did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Gracious Heaven forbid it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What was your purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Firſt on my knees let me implore your Royal Pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My end was noble: as I thought, well ſuit|ing
The Honour of a Prince: I would have ſearch'd
Into the ſecrets of his heart by queſtions,
VVhether he had intended or conceived
Treaſon againſt your Highneſs, as it is
Preſum'd he did: for which he was committed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My ſelf for that was his Accuſer;
How durſt you then make a ſcruple at it?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Still relying on your Pardon, I had thought
T'have won confeſſion of it from himſelf.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Suppoſe he had confeſs'd it?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: I had then
Concluded there had been a Probabilitie
Of my poor mothers falſehood: yet I would have put
That Queſtion to him next.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And ſay
He had confeſs'd that too?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Then had I ſav'd
Your Laws a needleſs labour in his death;
And with the ſame hand made that mother child|leſs,
That by her folly forfeited her Husband.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: VVas that your reſolution? but ſuppoſe
He had denied all?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: All had then been nothing
But a Scandal to my mother and himſelf:
So good a Souldier would not be a lyer
To ſave an abject life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are
His Baſtard, not my ſon, in doing this.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: You are my King, would I could ſay, my Father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Within there!
Horatio, would you think it? this young ſtripling
Takes part againſt me with that Traytor Sforza.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Does your Grace think ſo?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Think ſo? I know it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then I know it too: Think, did you ſay? I think 'twas time to think it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I knew it not till now.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As I am true to th' Crown, juſt now I knew it too.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O do not ſo interpret, Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What can be ſaid againſt it? has not his Grace ſpoke it?
What muſt be done with him to pleaſe your Majeſty?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Convey him from my ſight, and let our Marſhal
Petruccio take him to ſafe cuſtody,
Till our further pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My King, and Fa|ther.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence with him I ſay.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Great Sir, your mercy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Did not I tell your Majeſty there was not,
But in the Queen, Petruccio, and my ſelf,
True Loyaltie in the Court? Away you Traytor|ling.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My Lord, you are too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What? in being true to th' Crown? O my Loyaltie!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No news yet? no return?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: We ſhall have, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You made not choiſe of men of Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: They were the ſame exaſperate caſhier'd Souldiers
That ſware ſo valiantly againſt Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Many that paſs for Souldiers dare ſwear va|liantly,
That dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Many that dare not fight,
Dare do a murther Madam, ſuch a tame one too.
I am confident they have kill'd her: however, I have done my beſt.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou haſt done nothing whilſt that woman lives.
The work was not ſo courſe, that your own hand
Could have diſdain'd it, Sir, if you had lov'd me.
So leave me, negligent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Her firſt months Majeſty hath wip'd out
The memorie of all her former dayes.
I muſt not loſe her though: this hand then ſoon
Muſt do the work, be 't not already done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How cheers my love? what ominous aſpect
Hath wrought this ſad Eclipſe upon that Beautie,
VVhoſe radiancie onely is my life?
Caſt by this veil of ſadneſs: quit my fears,
And from my Browes wipe off a ſcore of years.
No? what muſt then remove it? or diſpell
Theſe Clouds, that from the anguiſh of thy heart
Do caſt this ſhadow ore my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I muſt not, will not name it: but you ſaid
You would do ſomething, which it ſeems
Your wavering love neglects.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Can I neglect
A duty that belongs to my Alinda?
Speak it again: and by my firſt nights bliſs
I had with thee, by this kiſs, and by this,
Ile treble in performance all my promiſes.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Y' are dull in your performances: I will
Not name a requeſt the ſecond time, although my life,
Your dignitie, and your Kingdoms ſafetie,
Lie on the rack for 't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She will not name 't again:
Her laſt requeſt was for the head of Sforza,
Her arrogant proud Father, whoſe perverſneſs
Checq'd at her due promotion; and whoſe life
Swolne up with Popularitie, was my danger,
Threatning no leſs then ruine on my State.
She will not name 't again, poor tender ſoul,
Leſt ſhe might fall into th' interpretation
Of an unnatural child: yet for my ſafetie,
She ſuffers in deſire to have it done.
I have prevented her deſire, 'tis done:
I know Petruccio his Antagoniſt,
Who had my warrant and Signet for it,
VVould not be ſlack in th' execution.
Come, ſweet, be fearleſs: that which your mild good|neſs
Is now ſo timerous to name, is done.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is ſhe purſu'd and put to death?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What ſhe?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Nay, I have ſaid again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sforza, my deareſt life, th' unnatural Homi|cide
That ſought thy life and mine, is put to death.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: VVhat, my dear Father?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: VVas it not your Deſire?
Here comes ſure Teſtimony: ſpeak Petruccio;
I will not ask, Is 't done? but ſpeak the manner
How Sforza di'd.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A ſelf-wil'd obſtinate man:
Such as he liv'd he di'd: and gracious Madam,
That a more bloody Spectacle ſhould not move
Your tender nature to compunction, I brought
But this inſeparate Adjunct of his malicious Head
Againſt you, the King, and the whole Kingdoms good.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: This is a token moſt infallible,
The Jewel that none but the cold hand of Death
Could raviſh from him: 'Tis done:
The fear of him is like a ſtorm blown ore:
'Tis done but this is yet but part of that full ſatis|faction
That muſt confirm my ſafetie: Pray my Lord,
You fatal inſtrument of my Fathers blood,
Let me not look upon you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay Alinda,
You muſt not be ſo ſad: your gentle ſorrow
In thoſe obſequious Tears expreſs'd, ſhew nature
And Filial pietie as he was your Father:
But think upon your wrongs, my dangers, and your own.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, think you withall, a Father
Is not ſo early forgot. But ſorrow leave me,
And do you give me leave to think, that now
It is no leſs a Childs part to embrace
Revenge then ſorrow for a Fathers loſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How means my love?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: She lives that was his Ruine.
You may remember whom I mean: Eulalia.
Till now, I had no Plea againſt her life:
Onely my care of you might wiſh her Death,
For your ſecurity. Her fowl Adultery
And ſecret Practices againſt your Crown,
Were nothing unto me, compar'd with this.
Now I have loſt a Father: ſhe the cauſe:
He ſuffers, ſhe ſurvives: where are your Laws?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet, be content.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Content your ſelf great Sir,
With your black infamie: ſit down content
On your Majeſtick Throne, the Preſident
Of Capital contented Cuckolds, do,
Till all your Subjects dance the Hornpipe too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay dear Alinda, do but think—

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Think what?
VVhat on a courſe to be reveng'd on you?
To ſerve you in that kind my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O torment!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Or rather, let me think your luſtful purpoſe
VVas but to rob me of my Virgin-Honour.
And that you put her by but for a time,
Until my youth had quench'd your Appetite;
Then to recal her home to your embraces.
She is your wife it ſeems then ſtill: not I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have awak'd me from a Lethargie
In which I was confounded: now I ſee
She and mine Honour cannot live at once:
She dies, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And you may conſider
A little further yet Sir, if you pleaſe:
You Father and maintain a Son (your own
I cannot ſafely ſay, and therefore more
Is my vexation) who demeans himſelf
Not towards me, like one that were your wife.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hee's alſo doom'd already, my Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It may prevent a greater ſtrife hereafter,
Should he but live t'inherit Lands and Titles
That muſt belong to yours and my ſucceſſion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy wiſdom inſpir'd me: all ſhall be
(Be thou but my Alinda) rul'd by thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Seal you that Grant: with this kiſs I Seal mine:
My glories were eclips'd, but now they ſhine.

div.head: Scoen. I.
div.stage: Enter Poggio, Lollio, two Countrey-men with Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Y'Are welcome Friends, your prayers and good wiſhes
Are comforts to me, yet without danger of the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Madam, the Court in all the Braverie
It boaſts and borrows, cannot ſo rejoyce
In the bright ſhining Beauty of their Queen,
As we in your enjoying in this plainneſs.
Their Bells, and Bonfires, Tilts and Tournaments,
Their Feaſts and Banquets, Muſicks and coſtly ſhews
(How ere unpaid for) ſhall not outpaſs our loves.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Be you as confident, I will not wrong
A man among you: therefore pray reſerve
What is your own, and warrant your own ſafety.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: But how you'll live, we know not: we are now
In our old former Health: the Countrey's cur'd,
Your Practice at an end: unleſs you had
The common gift of moſt Phyſitians,
To make as many ſick, as you make ſound,
You will not find a Patient in ſeven years.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: But I have other Arts: ſufficient skill
In works of ſeveral kinds, the Needle, Loome,
The Wheel, the Frame, the Net-Pin: and choice of
Fingers works are moſt familiar with me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: And can you handle the Bobbins well, good Woman?
Make ſtatute-Lace? you ſhall have my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: And mine, to make Tape-Purles: can you do it?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes, and teach all your children works to live on.
The which, together with my own labour,
May bring ſufficient for my maintenance:
Without the idle help of Begging, Borrowing,
Or any way infringing the Kings Command.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: You'l have a help beyond himſelf, but bor|rowing.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Something I have in Book, to help their know|ledge,
And by practiſe give them literature.
Then when theſe ſerious works and ſtudies toil us,
For Recreation, yet with equal skil,
VVee'l practice divers Inſtruments, Songs and mea|ſures,
That ſhall invite the Powers above to ſmile
On the content of which we them beguile.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Well Miſtris, ours is the voice of the whole Countrey;
All which, or what you pleaſe of it, is yours:
Take this Houſe: make your choice of ſervants.
Take our children: make your own Rates for their Education.
Our Purſes and our lives are free to you:
Get what you can, that's your own: will this pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes gentle Friends, and with aſmuch content
As ere I found in height of Government.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Take your poſſeſſion then: and let
Poſteritie record, that without grieving
A Royal Queen once Traded for her living.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Eho, oh, io, where is my learned ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Why ſeem you ſo diſtracted?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Alas what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Sure, ſure, his Scholars have over-Ma|ſter'd him, and whipt him out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Corpus inane animae, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray ſpeak, what chance has happened?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Non eſt narr andi locus: Go forth and ſee. Th'
enraged Rurals are in an uproar lowd, each one an Hercules furens, a formidabilis formidandus Hoſtis and quite againſt the Law
sp.l: Of noſtrum eſt injuriam non inferre,
Are on the point of making themſelves merry,
In hanging thoſe ill deſtin'd men by th' neck
That ſought ſo late to give your neck the check.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let us flie to reſcue them.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Yet I hope
Your haſt will bring you ſhort to cut the Rope.

div.head: Scoen. III.
div.stage: Enter Lollio, Poggio, and guard, with Fabio and Strozza.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Bring 'em away to preſent execution:
They have lien too long upon the Countreys charge.
We have given 'em bread and water a whole for|night.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: You dare not do't: what Law are we con|demn'd by?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Dare we not do't? that word's an hanging matter
Here in our Civil Government: dare not do 't Sir?
VVee'l do't; and when 'tis done, wee'l argue Law with you.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: When you have tane our lives, you'l lay the
Law to us: you cannot be ſo Barbarous.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Impudent Traytors! how dare you ſay we cannot? yet becauſe we graciouſly are pleas'd to put the Law out of our hands, and make you hang your ſelves, Ile give you Reaſon: Silence on your lives. Firſt, know, lewd men, y' are Traytors to the King, In offering to be wiſer then his Judgement, Which was but Baniſhment to the good Eulalia:
sp.l: Seeking moſt Trayterouſly to take the life
Of (I do not ſay the Queen, but) the Kings wife
Of moſt happy memory.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The good Eulalia?

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: the Kings wife?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: That was:
You ſhall not catch us tripping Sir,
VVe are more than your match.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Good I do ſay ſhe is, and good again
I dare pronounce he 〈◊〉 that by dayly pain
VVorks for her dayly bread: and for bare hire,
Teacheth our children ſo, that we admire:
The Infants who have underſtanding more
Then we their Parents have, or then
Our Fore-fathers before us had.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But brother Lollio, make not your ſpeech ſo long: what is 't to them? they'l carry none on 't to th' 'other world: let's do what we came to do, e'en hang 'em. Then, as I ſaid, wee'l argle it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: But brother Poggio, better 'tis they live
A minute two or three, then ſuch a Speech
As I am now upon, be loſt.
sp.stage: Enter Lodovico, Pedro, Curate, Andrea, Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: See what y' have won by your delay! if ſhe prevent not now
The good we meant her, I dare hang for 'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: In tempore venimus with a Reprieve, quod omnium Rerum eſt Primum.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Alas, what mean you neighbours? would you now
For all my labours and my Prayers for you,
Blaſt me with curſes of expiring men?
What treſpaſs have I done you, that for me
You put theſe men to death againſt my will?

sp.speaker: Fab. Stroz.
sp.l: We do applaud your mercy, gracious Queen.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: There now, there they deſerve hanging for that:
They call you Queen, againſt the Proclamation.
Dare you maintain 'em in't, and now ſpeak for 'em?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: No, I condemn their faults, and blame their lives;
But have nor Power nor will to judge the men:
You have the will; but to aſſume the Power,
You take the Kings Right from him: you tranſgreſſe
As much his Laws in ſpilling of their blood,
As they had done in mine, had they prevail'd.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: They do not intend to ſpill their blood, Countrey woman, they would but ſtrangle them: never pierce the skin, nor make 'm an hair worſe men, if you conſider rightly what they are.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: But to the point. This is the All and ſome: We meant you a good turn, and for your ſake t' have hang'd 'em right or wrong. Now ſince you will needs ſtand in your own highway of womens wiſdom, which is wilfulneſs

sp.speaker: (Cur.
sp.p: A moſt Elegant Figure!) Let'em and pleaſe you come to the Gallows another day for killing you out right: who can help it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oraculouſly ſpoken: which of the Sages could ſaid more?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: 'Tis not unknown to you, that I can ſpeak like a Sage, and am one of the Sages of our Precinct here for the Laytie, though your learning lie another way among us. I am a Sage, and will be a Sage.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: And ſo am I, and will be: and but that wiſe woman, which is as much to ſay as a fool for her la|bour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Another elegant Figure.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But that, I ſay, ſhe has gain-ſaid it, we would; yet to ſhew our ſelves Sages, hang 'em up for Scarcrowes, to fright all their fellows for coming from Court to kill women in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: O how I love a Sage! how many Sages do you allow in your Precinct?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Some three or four main Heads: we have now only Pedro, Poggio and my ſelf:
sp.l: But we have many Powers under us:
Theſe now are Powers that execute our Commands.
There is as much difference between a Sage and a Power,
As between a Judge and a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: But is not the learned Curate a Sage amongſt ye?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No, as I ſaid before, their learning lies another way: we allow not our Clergie any Tem|poral Offices, for reaſons known unto our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray let me have a Sages place amongſt ye then: I long to be a Sage.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Brother Andrea, you ſhall have my voice in your Election.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Sage Brother Lollio, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: But will ye now, if miſericordially
This gracious Foeminine preſerve your lives
from the Gallow Tree,
Become new men indeed?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I know they will
When they conſider the moſt dangerous ſin,
That threw them on their deſperate Attempt,
And their eſcape from merited Puniſhment,
They cannot be ſo graceleſs, not to turn
To a reformed life: Firſt know, yong men,
Your former Act 'gainſt me an Innocent,
Was Perjurie by which I fell, yet flouriſh.
Conſider there how black and fowl your Sin
Is rendred by my Chryſtal innocence:
Your next Attempt againſt me, was blacker, Murder,
The very word ſounds horrow.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
Name it not then: but by your ſacred mercy,
Acquit us of the Doom which we ſo juſtly
Have drawn upon our ſelves: and we will ſpend
Our lives in rendring ſatisfaction
To your abuſed goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This is ſerious.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Or may the earth on which we kneel for favour,
sp.l: Forc'd by the weight of our deteſted Sins, open.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Quick devour us.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: So, enough:
Ile take your words.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But now you muſt reveal
By whom you have been wrought to theſe fowl Practices.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: All, wee'l diſcover all, though juſtly then we pay our lives to Law.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good neighbours, Lollio, Poggio, and Andrea, conduct them to my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: My ſelf alſo will to be their ſecurer con|voy go,
For fear the Ruſticks may preſume again
To ſtretch theſe penitent necks with halter ſtrain.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You ſhall do well: I thank your Charity.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Well, ſince in theſe we are prevented thus,
Come more, wee'l hang 'em, or they ſhall hang us.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Make me but once a Sage, and then fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt be one next Seſſions, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: When we have tane theſe mens confeſſions,
Ile write at large each paſſage to the King,
Againſt the good Eulalia's will or knowledge

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Ile be your faithful Meſſenger, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thanks my good Pedro: but remember Silence.
So deep in thought good Madam?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Never enough in contemplation of my Hap|pineſs.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: It is your Heavenly mind that ſweetens all things.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: VVhat's the matter man?
Doubtleſs and without all peradventure, more miracles.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.p: The news, good neighbour.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: O neigbours Poggio and Lollio, ſuch a news, ſuch a Diſcoverie, ſuch a thing is come to paſs, ſuch a buſineſs is come to light, as your hearts never heard, your Tongues never thought, nor your ears ever utter'd: you cannot hear it, but it will drown you in a Sea of Admiration, never to riſe again in your right wits.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Now am I mad till I hear it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt tell me firſt whether it be good or bad, or Ile not hear it.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: It is good or bad I aſſure you: and there|fore you may be gone.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I mean which is it? good or bad?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: I ſay it is good and bad: and you may both ſtay and be gone, hear it or hear it not, an't' pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay thou art in thy Jibes now: how good or how bad is thy news?
sp.l: I pray thee neighbour, I do pray thee how good or bad is it?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: Nay then it is neither good nor bad, but both: the beſt and the worſt that ever you heard in your life, and the worſt ſhall out firſt: what do you think of the woman that we have got among us?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Who, the holy woman? that we are all ſo bound to pray for? I hope no ill's betide her.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: Come, ſhee's a witch: flatly and plainly ſaid to be a witch.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Did not I tell you ſhe was an unknown woman, and therefore a good one, quoth you? but ſay I, doubt|leſly; and without all peradventure, all that ſhe did was but a kind of witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: It cannot, fie, it cannot be: how is ſhe found ſo? Countr. I do not ſay ſhee's found a witch, but ſhe's accus'd for one.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: By whom is ſhe accus'd?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: By two brave men at Arms that came from Court
VVith purpoſe to have kill'd her for the ſame.
To be ſhort, They found her out, and naked ſwords they drew:
But as they thought to have thruſt her through and through,
They both dead Palſie-ſtruck fall to the ground.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: And had no ſtrength but of their Tongues to wound
The Fame ſhe had.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Vertue can want no Foes,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: VVith that they cryed ſhe was a witch, and ſwore
She alſo was that Queen which for a whore
The King had turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: This is indeed the beſt news thou couldſt bring.
Now doubtleſly and without all peradventure, 'tis the Queen indeed: and if ſhe be not a witch, I am ſorry I thought ſo, with all my heart: where be thoſe men? wee'l hang'm preſently.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: No, the Queen, if ſhe be the Queen, will not have them hurt more then they be: we wete about to execute 'em: but ſhe would not ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Goodneſs it ſelf!

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay without all peradventure, if there be goodneſs above ground, I ſaid, and I ſay it again, 'tis in that woman.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p:
She would have cur'd 'em preſently her ſelf: but could not do't, becauſe the cruel Caitifs
would not confeſſe their ſins, as ſhe made us, you know, before her gift could cure us: by the ſame token I ſuffered an hours torment that I might have ſcap'd, becauſe I was ſo loath to bring out that naughtie buſineſs betwixt me and the Millers wife.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: 'Twas well you confeſs'd at laſt.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: I, and they will be glad to confeſs, before they be able to ſtir hand or foot, I warrant: and ſo I told 'm when I lodg'd 'em both lovingly together upon ſtraw in my Barn, too good for 'em; and ſo I told 'em too, for being Traytors to her Holineſs.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: But where's our Holy woman?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Our Queen wee'l call her now, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Coming this way to her Court-Cottage here, but very ſlowly, though our two new neighbours make the beſt way they can for her through the Peo|ple that preſs upon her ſo with thanks and offerings for their new Healths: but ſhe takes not ſo much for curing of a thouſand mortal People, as I have ſpent in Turpentine and Tarre to keep my Flocklings cleanly in a Spring time. Hark, ſhe comes: this is her Muſick where ere ſhe goes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Depart good neighbours, good people all de|part: ſhee'l come abroad again to morrow.
Within Heaven bleſs our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: She thanks you all good People, pray de|part,
To morrow you ſhall have the ſecond part:
She ſhall appear again unto you; pray depart,
The men in Peace, the Wives in quietneſs,
And let your bigger children ſtill the leſs.
Heaven bleſs our Holy woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: So, now the Hubbub's gone: I pray paſs on.
I ſhall be as weary of the Cottage, as of the Court,
If this noiſe hold: here's thruſting and crowding
As much as there, onely here they have leſs Pride.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVas ever comfort in the Court like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I never liv'd till now.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Here come more of our weather-headed wiſe neighbours.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs our Holy woman.
Heaven bleſs your Holineſs.
Nay then Heaven bleſs our Sacred Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This Homage fits not me.
We had not liv'd but by your ſacred means;
And will no longer live then be your Subjects.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You go about to caſt away your lives:
In ſerving or in ſuccouring me, you fall
Into Rebellion againſt the King.
We have no King nor Queen but you.
Heaven bleſs your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs your Majeſtie.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: That was pronounc'd bravely; O my brave new neighbours!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Y' are Traytors All.
In honouring our Soveraign?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I, well ſaid, hold her to it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: How dare you call me ſo?
VVe dare, and can prove it good and lawful.
This Province is engag'd unto you Madam,
The King made it your Joynture: and we find
No reaſon but you inſtantly poſſeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVhat, and the King alive?
He's dead to you.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, he's dead to you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: VVell ſaid again: that's a ſound point, be|ſworn
Theſe be true Blades.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I tremble but to hear you,
And will not live an hour amongſt you more
But with this freedom, To uſe my fair obedience to the King.
You ſhall obey the King then, and we'll obey your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let that Title die with my late Fortune:
Remember it no more, but let me be
As one of you; nay rather, an Inferior,
Or I from this abiding muſt remove:
Of which I firſt made choice in truth for love.
O Madam!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Take heed good neighbours,
Beware how you give Dignitie or Title; therein you may tranſgreſs.
No whit good Madam. Obſerve the Dialect of France,
And you ſhall find Madam given there in Courteſie,
To women of low Fortunes, unto whom
'Tis held a poore addition, though great Queens
Do grace and make it Royal.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: 'Tis then the Greatneſs of
The Perſon dignifies the Titles, not it the Perſon.
And in that, Madam, you are in your content
Above all Title's proper to great Princes:
But ſetting this aſide, how thrive your Scholars?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: We go fairly on. [Enter 1. Girl.] look you Sir,
Here's one that knew no letter in the Book
Within theſe ten days, can read hitherto,
And waits for a new leſſon: proceed hither—
And at your hour Ile hear you.

sp.speaker: 1. Girl.
sp.l: Yes for|ſooth Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p:
Good Girl, well ſaid: nay, nay, hold up your head: ſo, ſo, 'tis very well: let's ſee your Samplar:
what an hearts eaſe is here! Lod. Right in its per|fect Colours.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Nay ſhee'l do well: now take me out this Flower. Keep your work clean, and you ſhall be a good Maid. Enter 3. Girl. Now where's your writing book?

sp.speaker: 3. Girl,
sp.p: 'Tis here for|ſooth. Pray ſhall I haye a Joyn-hand Copy next?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: No child, you muſt not Joyn-hand yet: you muſt your letters and your minums better firſt. Take heed, you may Joyn-hand too ſoon, and ſo mar all: ſtill youth deſires to be too forward. Go take your Lute, and let me hear you ſing the laſt I taught you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Whither do you preſs? who would you ſpeak withall?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: O Sir, for Charity ſake give us acceſs unto the holy woman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who are you? or from whence?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We are poor Pilgrims man and wife, that are upon our way ſtruck with ſad pain and ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Alas poor Pilgrims! here's ſhe muſt do you good.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: How divine Juſtice throwes my Enemies in|to my hands? what are your griefes?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: My wife is ſtruck with dumbneſs.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Hold a little,
That's the greateſt grief a woman can endure:
But trouble not thy ſelf to ſeek for cure.
Too many a man i'th' world will change with thee
A wife that of her Language is too free,
And give good Boot.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray Sir be you ſilent.
And where's your pain?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here in this hand;
Which I deſire to ſhew in ſome more privacie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Becauſe your Blow cannot be ſafely given here, you think.
O ſinful wretch! thou hadſt no pain till now;
Nor was ſhe dumb till divine Providence
Now at this inſtant ſtruck her. It is now
Juſt as thou ſaiſt: and juſtly are you puniſhed
For treacherous counterfeits. Lodowick ſearch his hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: His hand is wither'd, and lets fall a Knife.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: As ſharp to do a miſchief as ere was felt on.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Now take off his falſe Beard: ſee if you know him,
And let the woman be unmuffled.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O Divels!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: O the laſt couple that came out of Hell!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Theſe are the other two that damn'd them|ſelves
In perjurie againſt you at your Tryal.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: How do you maſter Doctor, and Miſtreſs Midwife?
Is this the Pen your Doctorſhip preſcribes with?
This might ſoon write that might cure all diſeaſes:
And are theſe the Labours you go to, Miſtreſs Mid|night?
VVould you bring women to bed this way?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O damnable conſpirators!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray take 'm hence, their time 's not come for cure yet.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Come away Pilgrims: we'll cure 'em for you,
If your own ſalves can cure you: O my ſweet Pil|grims.
Fough, they ſtink of Treaſon damnably
VVhat, ſhall we hang'm? drown 'em? or burn 'em?
They ſhall taſte fortie deaths, then take their own.

sp.p: I, come away with 'em: they ſhall die fortie times without peradventure,

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: You ſhall loſe me, if you do any violence to any of 'em: but let'm be lodg'd with thoſe we took to day: Ile feed 'em all.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: They'l be a jolly com|pany.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray do as I intreat.
You ſhall in all command us.

sp.p: Ile make my Barn a ſpittle for your conſpira|tors till it be top full, and then ſet fire on't, and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Do you no harm, and fear none: ſend your Children.

sp.speaker: 2. Omn.
sp.l: Long live our Queen.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Your Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?
Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: our School-Miſtreſs, we would ſay.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVe live ſecure in ſpight of Foes: and ſee,
Where Heaven protects, in vain is Treacherie:
VVho ſays out State is low, or that I fell
When I was put from Court? I did not riſe
Till then, nor was advanc'd till now. I ſee
Heaven plants me 'bove the reach of Treachery.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O happie, happie Saint!
sp.stage: Ex. Ruſtici with Doct. and Midwife.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.stage: Enter Flavello, alias Alphonſo, with a Letter to Eulalia, Poggio and Lollio following.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I would ſhe had a Councel: ſhe ſhall have a Councel,
And we will be the Heads thereof,
Though I be put to the pains to be Preſident my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: It is moſt requiſite for her ſafety: her danger may be great.
A good guard then in my opinion were more requi|rable.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: 'Tis well conſider'd: ſhe ſhall have a Guard too: and we will be the limbs thereof, though I be put to the trouble of Captain on't my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: You will put on all Offices, yet count 'em pain and trouble.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Yes, and perform 'em too here in our Court of Conſcience, for here's no other profit to hinder the Dutie: let them above do what they liſt; we will have as much care of our School-Miſtreſs, as they of their Semiramis: I ſpeak no Treaſon nor no trifles neither, if you mark it. But ſhe muſt never know this care of ours, She'll urge the Statute of Relief againſt it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: This is ſome Courtier ſure that's with her; he ſmells illfavordly.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: That made me dog him hither.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: He ſhall not have her out of ſight, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Nor out of reach neither: a miſchief's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: No Superſcription, nor any names unto it. Moſt Royal and moſt wronged Soveraign Miſtreſs: (that muſt needs be me.) Be happily aſſured your Reſtauration is at hand; And by no leſs means then by her Death that uſurps your Dignitie: (a plain conſpiracie againſt Alinda in my be|half.) All ſhall be determined at Nicoſia, by
Nameleſs.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: You know not the contents then, and are bound by Oath you ſay not to reveal the ſenders of this Letter.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It is moſt true: onely thus much I tell you, they are your noble and beſt choſen Friends.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Heaven! can it be, that men in my reſpect can plunge into ſuch danger?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: So Madam, this being all I had in charge,
I muſt crave leave (indeed I do not like this
Oportunitie, nor well the countenances of theſe Hobnols.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You are no meſſenger of ſuch ill Tidings
To part ſo ſlightly: indeed you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: She's honied with the newes: I have al|ready
Madam my Reward, and will no longer ſtay.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Then I muſt ſay, you ſhall ſtay: or Ile ſend
A cry as loud as Treaſon after you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You'l wrong yourſelf and Friends then.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: You wrong your ſelf Sir, and we charge you ſtay.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By the command of Peaſants?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: How! you choplogical Raſcal, Peaſants!

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Down with him into utter darkneſs.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: No-violence good Friends: but if you will detain him
Till I give order for his libertie,
You do the State good ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: May it do you Service?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: The State is finely ſerv'd already.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Me moſt of all.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Hell cannot hold him faſter then.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Mad Aſſe, hold your prating till ſhe calls you:
Mean time you are faſt: 'twas time we were a Councel or a Guard.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I thank thee Providence, I dreamed not of ſuch ready help.
I am ſtruck through with wonder at this Letter:
I could not at the firſt but think't a Bayt
To catch my willingneſs to ſuch an Act;
Or Gullerie to mock my Hopes or wiſhes,
In caſe I had ſuch: therefore I deſired
The Meſſengers reſtraint from being my Relator:
But now a ſtrong Belief poſſeſſes me,
A ●oble Fury has ſtirr'd up ſome Friends
To this high enterprize: whereby I gather
My cauſe is weigh'd above, whence I ſhall ſee
How well my patience over-rules my wrong,
And my Foes ruin'd with mine Honours ſafety.
But let my better Judgement weigh thoſe thoughts,
I do not ſeek revenge, why ſhall I ſuffer it?
My cauſeleſs injuries have brought me Honour,
And 'tis her ſhame to hear of my miſ-hap.
And if by Treachery ſhe fall, the world
Will judge me acceſſarie, as I were indeed
In this foreknowledge of the foul intent,
Should I conceal it.
Then here's the trembling doubt which way to take▪
Whether to riſe by her Deſtruction,
Or ſink my Friends, diſcovering their pretence.
Friends have no Priviledge to be treacherous:
She is my Soveraignes wife, his chief content;
Of which to rob him, were an act of horrour
Committed on himſelf. The queſtion's then,
Whether it be more foul ingratitude
To unknown Friends, and for an act of Sin,
Then to be treacherous to the Prince I love?
It is reſolv'd: Ile once more ſee the Court.
O my good Patrons, I muſt now intreat
Means for my Journey to attend the King,
On a diſcoverie for the preſent ſafetie
Of his fair Queen: ſhe will be murder'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: And let her go: we have ſhut up your news-bringer ſafe enough, will keep you by your favour, ſhort enough from hindring ſuch a work.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Dear Friends, a ſmall matter will prevent this world of dangers.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Would you have us to become Traytors, to
Supply your wants againſt the Proclamation?
If you be well, remain ſo: your Iuduſtry
Can keep you here: but for a Journey, that
Requires Horſes and Attendants: money muſt he had▪
Which we have not for ſuch an idle purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O hear me.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Will you neglect your Houſe and Trade to meddle any more with State-matters?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: And bring our necks in danger to aſſiſt you?
Let your own counſell adviſe you to ſtay.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How died the Boy?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gonzago Sir, your Son?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Son, my Son? you urge the name of Son
To work remorſe within me, when I ask
How died that Baſtard Boy; no Son of mine.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: His laſt words that he ſpake to me, were theſe;
Go, tell the King my Father, that his frown
Hath pierc'd my heart: tell him, if all his Land
Be peopled with obedient hearts like mine,
He needs no lawes to ſecond his diſpleaſure,
To make a general Depopulation:
But that he may not loſe ſo much, I pray
That in my Death his miſſe-plac'd anger die,
And that his wrath have double force 'gainſt thoſe
That to his Perſon and his Laws are Foes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did he ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And then, as if the Spirit of Prayer
Had onely been habitual in his ſoul,
He did implore Heaven's goodneſs to come down,
Lifting him hence to ſhine upon your Crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This Boy yet might be mine, though Sforza might have wrong'd me by the By.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: This done, he pray'd me leave the Roome. I wept: In ſooth I could-not chuſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, well, you wept, return'd, and found him dead in's Bed you ſay.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, in ſo ſweet a Poſture, as no Statuarie
With beſt of skill on moſt immaculate Marble
Could faſhion him an Image purer, ſlighter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I found his ſtretch'd-out fingers which ſo lately
Had clos'd his eyes, ſtill moiſtned with his tears;
And on his either cheek a tear undryed,
Which ſhone like Stars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It ſeems he wept and died.
Prithee no more: I cannot though forget
My threatnings were too ſharp: I muſt forget it.
I charge you that you leavy up our Army
Againſt thoſe Rebels that we hear give ſuccour
Unto the wretched cauſe of all my miſchiefes,
That hated ill-liv'd woman.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my dread liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The matter? ſpeaks; how does the Queen?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O the ſweet Queen! I fear, I fear, I fear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What fearſt thou? ſpeak the worſt I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I fear ſhe has a Moonflaw in her brains:
She chides and fights that none can look upon her.
Her Fathers Ghoſt, in her I think: here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Where's this King? this King of Clouts,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Fearful effect of Pride!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: This ſhadow of a King, that ſtands ſet up
As in a Preſs among the Raggs and Vizors
That repreſent his deceas'd Anceſtors.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What means my love?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Your love? where is your love?
Where is the preparation that you promis'd
Of ſtrength to tear in pieces that vile Witch
That lives my ſouls vexation? your love?
You are a load of torment: your delays
To my deſires are Helliſh cruelties.
Are theſe your Promiſes?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have given order with all ſpeed I could.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You could cut off an old man in a Priſon,
That could make no reſiſtance, and you could
Vex a poor Boy to death, that could but cry
In his defence; that you could do; but this
That has ſo much ſhew of fear or hardneſs,
As a few Peaſants to maintain a Strumpet
Againſt your Dignitie, is too much to do
For a poor coward King.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What a tyrannous Ambition
Has the Devil puff'd up this Bladder with!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I fear her wits are craz'd indeed. Alinda,
Hear me gentle love.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O my torment!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As I am true to the Crown, I know not what to ſay to this: ſhe's falling mad ſure.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No, no, you dare not do't: your Army may
Perhaps i'th' dangerous Action break a ſhin,
Or get a bloody noſe: it now appears
My Father (as 'twas voyc'd) was all your valour.
Y' have never a Mars or Cuckold-making General
Now left: and for your ſelf, you'r paſt it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: His' tother wife would not have us'd him thus.
Quiet Cuckoldrie is better then ſcolding chaſtitie all the world over.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I ſee diſtraction in her face.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Did all your brave Commanders die in Sforza?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By the Kings favour Madam (not to ſtir
The duſt of your dead Father) he has Souldiers
That know to lead and execute no leſs
Then did victorious Sforza.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.p: Sirrah! you have ſtirr'd more then his duſt; you have mov'd his blood in me, unto a Juſtice that claims, they trayterous head.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My head? and Trayterous? I do appeal un|to the King.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: A King? a Cobweb.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And ſhe the Spider in't I fear.
My Loyaltie knowes not how to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: If thou beeſt King, thou yet art but that King
That ows me love and life, and ſo my ſubject.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Indeed Alinda;—

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Yes indeed Gon|zago,
Life by inheritance: for my valiant Father
Whoſe life thou tookſt, gave thine, and ſo 'tis mine.
And for your love, you dare not wreſt it from me;
Therefore deny not now my juſt demand,
In that proud Traytors head.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She's mad be|yond all cure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Examine his offence, my dear Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is't not enough Alinda doth command it?
Are theſe the Articles you gave me grant of?
Is this the nothing that you would deny me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet, weigh but his offence.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: His Head is my offence: and give me that
Now, without pauſe, or by the ſtrength of Hercules
Ile take thee by the Horns, and writhe thine own off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go from her ſight Petruccio; levie up our Forces,
And let the Boy Gonzago be embowell'd,
And ſent as a forerunner of our Furie
Unto that Witch, contriver of theſe woes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis done, my liege.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Was ever woman barr'd her will, as I am?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Here's a fine woman ſpoil'd now, by humo|ring her at firſt, and cheriſhing her Pride.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Sure you have but mock'd me all this while:
I am no wife, no Queen, but ſilly Subject.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis a diſeaſe in her that muſt be ſooth'd:
Sweet, thou ſhalt have his Head.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O, ſhall I ſo?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go in, it ſhall be brought thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Mark what I ſay to bind you to your word:
Do it, or Ile not love you: I can change
Love into hate, hate into love moſt ſweetly:
Let that man live to morrow, Ile love him,
And do fine feats with him, ſuch as your tother wife
And Sforza did; but make much better ſport on't.
They were an old dry couple.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Take this, take all.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I leave all to your Kingly conſideration:
You know your charge: look to't, and ſo I leave you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What wild Affections do in women raign!
But this a Paſſion paſt all Preſident.
O 'tis meer Madneſs, mix'd with Divelliſh cunning,
To hurl me upon more and endleſs miſchiefes:
It has awak'd me to the ſight of thoſe
My fury (ſprung from Dotage) hath already
Laid in my Path, grim Spectacles of horror,
The blood of Sforza, and that tender Boy:
O let me think no further, yet ſtay there:
To plunge at firſt into too deep a Senſe
Of ſoul-afflicting terrours, drowns the Reaſon,
And ſtupifies the Conſcience, which delivers
Us over to an inſenſibilitie
Of our miſdeeds, and of our ſelves: juſt Heaven!
Afford me light to ſee I am miſled:
But let it not as lightning blaſt mine eyes,
Confound my Senſes, make me further ſtray,
For ever coming back to know my way.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How fares your Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O Horatio! ſhee's loſt, ſhee's loſt, Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would my wife were with her then:
And ſo would any good Subject ſay; I think.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What doſt thou think?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Marry I think (and ſo would any good Sub|ject think, I think) as your Majeſtie thinks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What doſt thou think of Loyaltie now?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Truly I think there's now not any warrant|able Loyaltie left but in Petruccio and my ſelf.
The Queen is now out of my Catalogue, and my Creed too.

div.head: Scoen. VIII.
div.stage: [A ſhout within] crying, Kill him, kill him: for Sforza, Sforza: kill him for the blood of Sforza, Sforza, &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What terrible, what hideous noiſe is this?
Kill him for Sforza, Sforza; kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Loyaltie defend me! I know not what to make on't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What art thou? ſpeak: hadſt thou the voice of Hell,
Denouncing all the Furies in't, I dare yet hear thee; ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O mighty Sir, Petruccio.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What of Petruccio?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O Petruccio! I tremble but to ſpeak him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shall I then with the Prophetique Spirit of a King
Speaks of Petruccio? he is turn'd Traytor,
And animates the Souldiers againſt me,
Upon the diſcontent Alinda gave him
Now in her Fury: is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, 'tis ſo: ne'er ask him for the matter:
I thought ſo, juſt, juſt as your Majeſtie thought it;
And find withall, that now you have not left
A Loyal heart but in Horatio's boſome,
Now that Petruccio fails: I fear'd 'twould come
To that: nay knew't: O hang him, hang him,
Falſe hearted villain! he was never right,
And ſo I always told your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The cry comes neerer ſtill: what does he mean,
To bring my Army on to Maſſacre
Me in my Houſe?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Dread Sir, vouchſafe atten|tion:
Petruccio is Loyal: 'tis his Loyaltie,
And moſt ſincere obedience to your will,
That brings him to the ruine of his life,
Unleſs your aweful Preſence make prevention.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is then his Loyaltie become his danger?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: As thus great Sir, in the late Execution
Of Death-doom'd Sforza, which the Souldier
(Not looking on your Juſtice, but the Feud
That was betwixt Petruccio and him)
Reſents as if it were Petruccio's Act,
Not yours, that cut him off: and ſtill, as madly
Bewitch'd with Sforza's love, as ignorant
Of the deſert of brave Petruccio,
They all turn head upon him: and as if
'Twere in his power to new create him to them,
They cry to him for Sforza, Sforza; or if not,
Petruccio's life muſt anſwer Sforza's blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Left you him in that diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: He did prevail
With much entreatie, by ſome private reaſons,
Upon their fury for an hours reſpite:
In which dear time 'tis onely you may ſave
Guiltleſs Petruccio from a timeleſs Grave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art a Souldier, art not?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: And have commanded in your Highneſſe Wars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Me thinks I ſhould remember, but Ile truſt thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I hope you'll be advis'd, though, how you run
Into this wild-fire of Rebellion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Fortune is more deſperate then his:
I am beſet and circled in with miſchiefes.
Way-laid with heaps of dangers every where:
Yet I will on: Kings were not made to fear.
Ile fetch him off, and the more readily,
For my miſpriſion of his Loyaltie.
Could I think that man falſe?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No Sir, nor I:
By all meanes fetch him off: that Loyal General
Is tenfold worth the whole Rebellious Army:
Save him, and hang them all.
sp.stage: Enter Petruccio with a Rabble of Souldiers, and two Captains, crying, Come, come, away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Have you no Faith, nor due obedience
Unto the King? this outrage is 'gainſt him,
In me he ſuffers.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: We obey the King,
And 'tis his Juſtice that we cut your throat,
For doing ſuch outrage in the death of our brave General,
That had you lives more then falſe drops of blood,
They were not all ſufficient ſatisfaction for his loſſe.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: Your limited hour draws on apace: Prepare.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He's come within that hour, that ſhall relieve me.
Where is he? is he come?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You are betray'd:
He's fled and gone: no ſuch man to be found.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then Faith is fled from man: is Sforza fled?
Why ſhould I wiſh to live, now Honour's dead?
Now take your bloody courſe, and in my fall,
Martyr the man that ſav'd your General.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Sav'd him? how ſav'd?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sforza lives.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's that? how's that? that, that again.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: As I now live, I ſet him free from Priſon,
Truſting unto his Honour to ſecure me,
In which I did abuſe the Kings Authoritie
To th' forfeit of my life.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: This ſounds: this ſounds.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: But does this ſound well from a Souldiers mouth?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: He is not now worthy of death, before He be well whipt for lying.
The King, the King, the King!

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: He could never come in a better time, to ſee how bravely we will do juſtice for him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How comes this Fury rais'd amongſt ye Souldiers?
Have you forgot my Laws and Perſon too?

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: We honour both thus low: now gives us leave
To look like men, and give your Highneſs welcome
To ſee a General of your Election
Die with a lie in's mouth: your Souldier here,
None of the good Queens old ones.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dare you both judge and execute this man?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: We dare to kill the Hangman of our General,
And think it fits our Office beſt: though you
Have Law enough to wave our care and pain,
And hang him up your ſelf: for he affirms
That he let Sforza live 'gainſt your command;
And that's the lie we treat of.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Ile give you all your Pardons, and him Honour,
To make that true. Sfor. Your Kingly word is taken.
Noble Petruccio, thou art diſengag'd:
And if the temper of the Kings high Anger
Blow ſtill above his Juſtice, let it cruſh
This cloud that holds a ſhower of innocent blood,
Willing to fall and calm his violent fury.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Our General lives: a Sforza, Sforza.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You have outdone me in Nobilitie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am all wonder: now this man appears
The Manſion and habitual Seat of Honour;
Of which he ſeems ſo full, there cannot be
An Angle in his breaſt to lodge ſo baſe
An Inmate as diſloyaltie: if ſo,
How was Eulalia falſe? or how Gonzago,
That tender Boy, the fruit of lawleſs luſt?
There I am loſt again: Great Power, that knoweſt
The ſubtletie of hearts, ſhew me ſome light
Through theſe Cymmerian miſts of doubts and fears,
In which I am perplex'd even to diſtraction:
Shew me, ſhew me yet the face of glorious Truth; where I may read
If I have err'd, which way I was miſled.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Enters. O my dread Lord!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy news?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my ſweet Soveraign!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou diſtracted too?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No Sir: The Queen, the Queen, the Queen's diſtracted,
And I am like to be, and you, and any man
That loves the King, unleſs ſome Conjurer
Be found to lay the Devil: I mean Sforza.
Sforza Sir (would you think?) that monſtruous Traytor
Sforza walks in the Court without a Head;
Appear'd unto the Queen: I found her talking with him,
Kneeling and praying him to give her Pardon;
Told him indeed 'twas ſhe that ſought his Head,
And that ſhe thought, that being now a Queen,
She might by her Prerogative take Heads,
Whoſe and as many as ſhe liſted: but
She promis'd ſhe would ſend it him again,
Or elſe Petruccio's firſt: or if he would forgive her
This time, ſhee'ld do ſo no more.
He ſeem'd he would not hear her: then ſhe beat
Her ſelf againſt the walls and floor, and flies
To free her ſelf by th' windows: calls for Poiſon,
Knife, Rope, or any thing, whereby to follow
Her moſt abuſed Father. What to make on't,
As I am true to th' Crown, I muſt refer
Onely unto your Majeſtie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O 'tis fearful!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Lord, you ſaw not th' Apparition, did you?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not I: I ſaw him not: nor has the Devil
Power in a Traytors ſhadow to appear
Unto a Loyal Subject. Hah! my Loyaltie
And Truth unto the Crown defend me!
See the very foreſaid Devil at my Elbowe,
Head and all now: avoid, attempt me not Satan,
I do conjure thee by all the vertues of a Loyal Courtier.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: They are all too weak to charm a Devil Sir;
But me they may, your Friend.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I defie thee Bubſebel.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What do you ſee, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look there, the Apparition, there it is;
As like the Traytor Sforza when he liv'd,
As Devil can be like a Devil—oh!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Fear not: he lives, and Loyal to the King.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Does the King ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Give me your hand my Lord,
The king will ſay ſo, if this be fleſh and blood.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I, if thou beeſt fleſh and blood: but how to believe that I know not, when my touch makes me ſweat out a whole ſhowre of pure Loyaltie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more, Horatio: I find that my credulitie
Has been wrought on unto my much abuſe,
And Sforza now appears an honeſt man.
